speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Now is the winter of our discontent

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Made glorious summer by this sun of York;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And all the clouds that lour'd upon our house

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Our bruised arms hung up for monuments;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Grim-visaged war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And now, instead of mounting barded steeds

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: To fright the souls of fearful adversaries,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: He capers nimbly in a lady's chamber

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I, that am rudely stamp'd, and want love's majesty

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: To strut before a wanton ambling nymph;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I, that am curtail'd of this fair proportion,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Cheated of feature by dissembling nature,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Into this breathing world, scarce half made up,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And that so lamely and unfashionable

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: That dogs bark at me as I halt by them;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Have no delight to pass away the time,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Unless to spy my shadow in the sun

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And descant on mine own deformity:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: To entertain these fair well-spoken days,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I am determined to prove a villain

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And hate the idle pleasures of these days.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: By drunken prophecies, libels and dreams,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: To set my brother Clarence and the king

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: In deadly hate the one against the other:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And if King Edward be as true and just

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: As I am subtle, false and treacherous,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: This day should Clarence closely be mew'd up,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: About a prophecy, which says that 'G'

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Of Edward's heirs the murderer shall be.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Dive, thoughts, down to my soul: here

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Clarence comes.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Brother, good day; what means this armed guard

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: That waits upon your grace?

speaker: CLARENCE
line: His majesty

speaker: CLARENCE
line: Tendering my person's safety, hath appointed

speaker: CLARENCE
line: This conduct to convey me to the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Upon what cause?

speaker: CLARENCE
line: Because my name is George.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Alack, my lord, that fault is none of yours;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: He should, for that, commit your godfathers:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: O, belike his majesty hath some intent

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: That you shall be new-christen'd in the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: But what's the matter, Clarence?  may I know?

speaker: CLARENCE
line: Yea, Richard, when I know; for I protest

speaker: CLARENCE
line: As yet I do not: but, as I can learn,

speaker: CLARENCE
line: He hearkens after prophecies and dreams;

speaker: CLARENCE
line: And from the cross-row plucks the letter G.

speaker: CLARENCE
line: And says a wizard told him that by G

speaker: CLARENCE
line: His issue disinherited should be;

speaker: CLARENCE
line: And, for my name of George begins with G,

speaker: CLARENCE
line: It follows in his thought that I am he.

speaker: CLARENCE
line: These, as I learn, and such like toys as these

speaker: CLARENCE
line: Have moved his highness to commit me now.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Why, this it is, when men are ruled by women:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: 'Tis not the king that sends you to the Tower:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, 'tis she

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: That tempers him to this extremity.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Was it not she and that good man of worship,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Anthony Woodville, her brother there,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: That made him send Lord Hastings to the Tower,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: From whence this present day he is deliver'd?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: We are not safe, Clarence; we are not safe.

speaker: CLARENCE
line: By heaven, I think there's no man is secure

speaker: CLARENCE
line: But the queen's kindred and night-walking heralds

speaker: CLARENCE
line: That trudge betwixt the king and Mistress Shore.

speaker: CLARENCE
line: Heard ye not what an humble suppliant

speaker: CLARENCE
line: Lord hastings was to her for his delivery?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Humbly complaining to her deity

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Got my lord chamberlain his liberty.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I'll tell you what; I think it is our way,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: If we will keep in favour with the king,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: To be her men and wear her livery:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: The jealous o'erworn widow and herself,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Since that our brother dubb'd them gentlewomen.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Are mighty gossips in this monarchy.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
line: I beseech your graces both to pardon me;

speaker: BRAKENBURY
line: His majesty hath straitly given in charge

speaker: BRAKENBURY
line: That no man shall have private conference,

speaker: BRAKENBURY
line: Of what degree soever, with his brother.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Even so; an't please your worship, Brakenbury,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: You may partake of any thing we say:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: We speak no treason, man: we say the king

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Well struck in years, fair, and not jealous;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: We say that Shore's wife hath a pretty foot,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: A cherry lip, a bonny eye, a passing pleasing tongue;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And that the queen's kindred are made gentle-folks:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: How say you sir? Can you deny all this?

speaker: BRAKENBURY
line: With this, my lord, myself have nought to do.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Naught to do with mistress Shore! I tell thee, fellow,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: He that doth naught with her, excepting one,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Were best he do it secretly, alone.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
line: What one, my lord?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Her husband, knave: wouldst thou betray me?

speaker: BRAKENBURY
line: I beseech your grace to pardon me, and withal

speaker: BRAKENBURY
line: Forbear your conference with the noble duke.

speaker: CLARENCE
line: We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: We are the queen's abjects, and must obey.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Brother, farewell: I will unto the king;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And whatsoever you will employ me in,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Were it to call King Edward's widow sister,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I will perform it to enfranchise you.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Meantime, this deep disgrace in brotherhood

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Touches me deeper than you can imagine.

speaker: CLARENCE
line: I know it pleaseth neither of us well.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Well, your imprisonment shall not be long;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Meantime, have patience.

speaker: CLARENCE
line: I must perforce. Farewell.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Go, tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Simple, plain Clarence! I do love thee so,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: If heaven will take the present at our hands.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: But who comes here? the new-deliver'd Hastings?

speaker: HASTINGS
line: Good time of day unto my gracious lord!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: As much unto my good lord chamberlain!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Well are you welcome to the open air.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: How hath your lordship brook'd imprisonment?

speaker: HASTINGS
line: With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must:

speaker: HASTINGS
line: But I shall live, my lord, to give them thanks

speaker: HASTINGS
line: That were the cause of my imprisonment.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: No doubt, no doubt; and so shall Clarence too;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: For they that were your enemies are his,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And have prevail'd as much on him as you.

speaker: HASTINGS
line: More pity that the eagle should be mew'd,

speaker: HASTINGS
line: While kites and buzzards prey at liberty.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: What news abroad?

speaker: HASTINGS
line: No news so bad abroad as this at home;

speaker: HASTINGS
line: The King is sickly, weak and melancholy,

speaker: HASTINGS
line: And his physicians fear him mightily.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Now, by Saint Paul, this news is bad indeed.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: O, he hath kept an evil diet long,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And overmuch consumed his royal person:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: 'Tis very grievous to be thought upon.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: What, is he in his bed?

speaker: HASTINGS
line: He is.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Go you before, and I will follow you.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: He cannot live, I hope; and must not die

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Till George be pack'd with post-horse up to heaven.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I'll in, to urge his hatred more to Clarence,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: With lies well steel'd with weighty arguments;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And, if I fall not in my deep intent,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Clarence hath not another day to live:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Which done, God take King Edward to his mercy,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And leave the world for me to bustle in!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: For then I'll marry Warwick's youngest daughter.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: What though I kill'd her husband and her father?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: The readiest way to make the wench amends

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Is to become her husband and her father:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: The which will I; not all so much for love

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: As for another secret close intent,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: By marrying her which I must reach unto.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: But yet I run before my horse to market:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: When they are gone, then must I count my gains.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Set down, set down your honourable load,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: If honour may be shrouded in a hearse,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: The untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Poor key-cold figure of a holy king!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Be it lawful that I invocate thy ghost,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: To hear the lamentations of Poor Anne,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaughter'd son,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Stabb'd by the selfsame hand that made these wounds!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Lo, in these windows that let forth thy life,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: I pour the helpless balm of my poor eyes.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Cursed be the hand that made these fatal holes!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Cursed be the heart that had the heart to do it!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Cursed the blood that let this blood from hence!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: More direful hap betide that hated wretch,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: That makes us wretched by the death of thee,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Than I can wish to adders, spiders, toads,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Or any creeping venom'd thing that lives!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: If ever he have child, abortive be it,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Prodigious, and untimely brought to light,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Whose ugly and unnatural aspect

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: May fright the hopeful mother at the view;

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: And that be heir to his unhappiness!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: If ever he have wife, let her he made

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: A miserable by the death of him

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: As I am made by my poor lord and thee!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Come, now towards Chertsey with your holy load,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Taken from Paul's to be interred there;

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: And still, as you are weary of the weight,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Rest you, whiles I lament King Henry's corse.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Stay, you that bear the corse, and set it down.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: What black magician conjures up this fiend,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: To stop devoted charitable deeds?

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Villains, set down the corse; or, by Saint Paul,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I'll make a corse of him that disobeys.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: Gentleman
line: My lord, stand back, and let the coffin pass.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Unmanner'd dog! stand thou, when I command:

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Advance thy halbert higher than my breast,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Or, by Saint Paul, I'll strike thee to my foot,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And spurn upon thee, beggar, for thy boldness.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: What, do you tremble? are you all afraid?

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Alas, I blame you not; for you are mortal,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: And mortal eyes cannot endure the devil.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Avaunt, thou dreadful minister of hell!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Thou hadst but power over his mortal body,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: His soul thou canst not have; therefore be gone.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Sweet saint, for charity, be not so curst.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Foul devil, for God's sake, hence, and trouble us not;

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Fill'd it with cursing cries and deep exclaims.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Behold this pattern of thy butcheries.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: O, gentlemen, see, see! dead Henry's wounds

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Open their congeal'd mouths and bleed afresh!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Blush, Blush, thou lump of foul deformity;

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: For 'tis thy presence that exhales this blood

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: From cold and empty veins, where no blood dwells;

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Thy deed, inhuman and unnatural,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Provokes this deluge most unnatural.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: O God, which this blood madest, revenge his death!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: O earth, which this blood drink'st revenge his death!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Either heaven with lightning strike the

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: murderer dead,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Or earth, gape open wide and eat him quick,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: As thou dost swallow up this good king's blood

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Which his hell-govern'd arm hath butchered!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Lady, you know no rules of charity,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Which renders good for bad, blessings for curses.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Villain, thou know'st no law of God nor man:

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: But I know none, and therefore am no beast.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: O wonderful, when devils tell the truth!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: More wonderful, when angels are so angry.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Vouchsafe, divine perfection of a woman,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Of these supposed-evils, to give me leave,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: By circumstance, but to acquit myself.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Vouchsafe, defused infection of a man,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: For these known evils, but to give me leave,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: By circumstance, to curse thy cursed self.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Some patient leisure to excuse myself.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Fouler than heart can think thee, thou canst make

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: No excuse current, but to hang thyself.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: By such despair, I should accuse myself.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: And, by despairing, shouldst thou stand excused;

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: For doing worthy vengeance on thyself,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Which didst unworthy slaughter upon others.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Say that I slew them not?

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Why, then they are not dead:

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: But dead they are, and devilish slave, by thee.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I did not kill your husband.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Why, then he is alive.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Nay, he is dead; and slain by Edward's hand.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: In thy foul throat thou liest: Queen Margaret saw

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Thy murderous falchion smoking in his blood;

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: The which thou once didst bend against her breast,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: But that thy brothers beat aside the point.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I was provoked by her slanderous tongue,

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: which laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Thou wast provoked by thy bloody mind.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Which never dreamt on aught but butcheries:

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Didst thou not kill this king?

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I grant ye.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Dost grant me, hedgehog? then, God grant me too

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: Thou mayst be damned for that wicked deed!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: O, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous!

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: The fitter for the King of heaven, that hath him.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE
line: He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Let him thank me, that holp to send him thither;

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Your bed-chamber.

line: I'll rest betide the chamber where thou liest!

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: You should not blemish it, if I stood by:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: As all the world is cheered by the sun,

speaker: LADY ANNE

speaker: GLOUCESTER

scene: SCENE II.  The same. Another street.
speaker: LADY ANNE

line: Weigh it but with the grossness of this age,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: You break not sanctuary in seizing him.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: The benefit thereof is always granted

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: To those whose dealings have deserved the place,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: And those who have the wit to claim the place:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: This prince hath neither claim'd it nor deserved it;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Then, taking him from thence that is not there,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: You break no privilege nor charter there.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Oft have I heard of sanctuary men;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: But sanctuary children ne'er till now.

speaker: CARDINAL
line: My lord, you shall o'er-rule my mind for once.

speaker: CARDINAL
line: Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?

speaker: HASTINGS
line: I go, my lord.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Where it seems best unto your royal self.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: If I may counsel you, some day or two

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Your highness shall repose you at the Tower:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Then where you please, and shall be thought most fit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: For your best health and recreation.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: I do not like the Tower, of any place.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: He did, my gracious lord, begin that place;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Is it upon record, or else reported

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Successively from age to age, he built it?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Upon record, my gracious lord.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: But say, my lord, it were not register'd,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Methinks the truth should live from age to age,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: As 'twere retail'd to all posterity,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Even to the general all-ending day.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Aside  So wise so young, they say, do never

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: live long.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: What say you, uncle?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I say, without characters, fame lives long.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Thus, like the formal vice, Iniquity,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I moralize two meanings in one word.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: That Julius Caesar was a famous man;

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: With what his valour did enrich his wit,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: His wit set down to make his valour live

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Death makes no conquest of this conqueror;

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: For now he lives in fame, though not in life.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: I'll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham,--

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: What, my gracious lord?

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: An if I live until I be a man,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: I'll win our ancient right in France again,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Aside  Short summers lightly have a forward spring.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Now, in good time, here comes the Duke of York.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Richard of York! how fares our loving brother?

speaker: YORK
line: Well, my dread lord; so must I call you now.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Ay, brother, to our grief, as it is yours:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Too late he died that might have kept that title,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Which by his death hath lost much majesty.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?

speaker: YORK
line: I thank you, gentle uncle. O, my lord,

speaker: YORK
line: You said that idle weeds are fast in growth

speaker: YORK
line: The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: He hath, my lord.

speaker: YORK
line: And therefore is he idle?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.

speaker: YORK
line: Then is he more beholding to you than I.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: He may command me as my sovereign;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: But you have power in me as in a kinsman.

speaker: YORK
line: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: My dagger, little cousin? with all my heart.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: A beggar, brother?

speaker: YORK
line: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give;

speaker: YORK
line: And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: A greater gift than that I'll give my cousin.

speaker: YORK
line: A greater gift! O, that's the sword to it.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: A gentle cousin, were it light enough.

speaker: YORK
line: O, then, I see, you will part but with light gifts;

speaker: YORK
line: In weightier things you'll say a beggar nay.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: It is too heavy for your grace to wear.

speaker: YORK
line: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: What, would you have my weapon, little lord?

speaker: YORK
line: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: How?

speaker: YORK
line: Little.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: My Lord of York will still be cross in talk:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Uncle, your grace knows how to bear with him.

speaker: YORK
line: You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me:

speaker: YORK
line: Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me;

speaker: YORK
line: Because that I am little, like an ape,

speaker: YORK
line: He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: He prettily and aptly taunts himself:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: So cunning and so young is wonderful.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: My lord, will't please you pass along?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Myself and my good cousin Buckingham

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Will to your mother, to entreat of her

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.

speaker: YORK
line: What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: My lord protector needs will have it so.

speaker: YORK
line: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Why, what should you fear?

speaker: YORK
line: Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost:

speaker: YORK
line: My grandam told me he was murdered there.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: I fear no uncles dead.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Nor none that live, I hope.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: An if they live, I hope I need not fear.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: But come, my lord; and with a heavy heart,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
line: Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Think you, my lord, this little prating York

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Was not incensed by his subtle mother

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: To taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: No doubt, no doubt; O, 'tis a parlous boy;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: He is all the mother's, from the top to toe.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Well, let them rest. Come hither, Catesby.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: As closely to conceal what we impart:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Thou know'st our reasons urged upon the way;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: What think'st thou? is it not an easy matter

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: To make William Lord Hastings of our mind,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: For the instalment of this noble duke

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: In the seat royal of this famous isle?

speaker: CATESBY
line: He for his father's sake so loves the prince,

speaker: CATESBY
line: That he will not be won to aught against him.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: What think'st thou, then, of Stanley? what will he?

speaker: CATESBY
line: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Well, then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: And, as it were far off sound thou Lord Hastings,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: How doth he stand affected to our purpose;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: And summon him to-morrow to the Tower,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: To sit about the coronation.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: If thou dost find him tractable to us,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Encourage him, and show him all our reasons:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: If he be leaden, icy-cold, unwilling,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Be thou so too; and so break off your talk,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: And give us notice of his inclination:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: For we to-morrow hold divided councils,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Wherein thyself shalt highly be employ'd.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Commend me to Lord William: tell him, Catesby,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: To-morrow are let blood at Pomfret-castle;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And bid my friend, for joy of this good news,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Give mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Good Catesby, go, effect this business soundly.

speaker: CATESBY
line: My good lords both, with all the heed I may.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?

speaker: CATESBY
line: You shall, my lord.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceive

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Chop off his head, man; somewhat we will do:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And, look, when I am king, claim thou of me

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: The earldom of Hereford, and the moveables

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Whereof the king my brother stood possess'd.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
line: I'll claim that promise at your grace's hands.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: And look to have it yielded with all willingness.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards

speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: We may digest our complots in some form.
